comments.commentBody: Look at the dreck that sits in Congress, peruse the ridiculous Supreme Court decisions that have declared corporations are "people" and opened the doors to money gushing into political campaigns, warch the clown car of people who run for president on the Republican side and see them run like hogs to the trough to a "meeting" with billionaire Sheldon Adelson hoping he'll toss some of his billions into their campaign coffers in return them doing whatever he wants after they are elected -- those are just a few of the things that have made us the dysfunctional mess of a country that is the US today.

Funny you should mention Longstreet; your history is rather selective. The encyclopediavirginia tells the whole story: "During Reconstruction, he accepted political appointments from the Republican Party. Although traditionally conservative on social issues, he endorsed biracial politics as the South's future. As commander of the Louisiana state militia, Longstreet risked his life defending black civil rights against white supremacist violence. These actions alienated Longstreet's wartime comrades-in-arms and effectively erased his reputation as a Confederate hero."
That, rather than anything he did or didn't do at Gettysburg explains why the United Daughters of the Confederacy refused to send flowers for his grave.
Longstreet learned more in a decade than you have in 150 years.
This has to be fake, right?
Sadly no... Sanchez has been saying this stuff for years, never listening to anyone else, never learning.

As long as a Rebel Yell can be made, Southern sacrifices and victories will not be forgotten:

And this is a fundamental principle of justice: One which I think should be always upheld. That it were better for a hundred murderers to go free than to have one innocent person convicted. This is the basis for the 'Beyond Reasonable Doubt' principle. It is one that any ethically and morally upright person would surely agree with. It is a price we have to pay for justice.

People, please don't think the legal system is any more responsible. See this first hand account of recent "alleged" rape at Dartmouth - if you can handle the stomach turning: http://www.dartmouthchange.org/sean-clauson/ - The problem we are dealing with - and is hopefully coming to light - is hugely ingrained misogyny. See comment: "....a bailiff remarked to me that the evidentiary threshold of the legal system is setup in such a way as to allow ten rapists to go free if it means preventing even one falsely accused rapist from going to jail."

Dennis: the point is that freedom without limit, freedom without the imposition of cultural norms, freedom as an absolute right ... leads to a Hobbesian world of fear and abuse.  Rape is put an instance of that Hobbesian world.  So the answer is to reverse that trend.  To impose constraints on freedom.  And that is not a concept familiar to a university setting.  It requires a Hobbesian social contract, maintained by a constraining authority.  Yes, the rule is simple "no rape."  But that is too simplistic  a view of what is going on here.

What age are the students we are talking about here. If over eighteen, then I would imagine that by that age they should have had such good grounding in morality that universities need not take parenting roles. Come on, these are institutions of higher learning we are talking about here. And these students are meant to be the best society has come up with?

Derick:  These are kids aged 18 -22, with raving hormones, first time away from home on a long term basis and no "summer camp counselors" in the bunk next door.  And the prevailing ethic is "anything goes."  Yes, the rules of law apply.  But college campuses are enclaves of privilege and exemption.  Under age drinking ... no problem.  Sexual aggression by both males and females ... no problem.  Hooking up for anonymous sexual encounters (no relationships, please) ... no problem.  Drugs ... no problem.  Watching Game of Thrones depict rape and violence as entertainment ... no problem.  Yes, the university administration can be faulted, and should be faulted, for woefully poor responses to complaints.  Yes, normal respect for the dignity of others can be insisted upon.  Yes, "no rape" is a simple rule that all should understand.  But, an environment has been created that fosters a "no rules" freedom that classically has been described by Hobbes. Yes, respecting human dignity can be re-emphasized.  Yes, more effective administrative responses to complaints of rape can, and should be, be instituted.  But that is just a "response."  To fix the problem requires a re-examination of what the academic community has become.  It's all in Hobbes:  what's needed is a re-vitalized social contract respecting human dignity and obeying the rule of law, and a "sovereign" (the administration) able and willing to impose order.

It began with women and men on the same floor in dorms, then sharing same bathrooms.  Violent video war games.  Game of Thrones and the recurrence of rape.  Along the way, women took pride in being independent sexual actors ... sexual predators could now be male or female.  And it has ended up with rampant sexual assault.  Could anyone have foreseen this.  Of course.  Colleges have abandoned the exercise of in loco parentis responsibility.  That went out with the 1950s.  So here we are.  It's just a hook up culture.  And that, innately, is a violent culture, disrespectful of human dignity.  The freedom to do whatever you want turns out to have a very ugly and dark side.  Good luck putting that genie back in the bottle.

Wow, I didn't know there were police stationed in campuses in the US. In the UK there are security officers, not police.

Rape is a violent crime and as such should be reported directly to the police. I would suggest any victim of violent crime, whether a student or not, immediately report it to law enforcement. Campus police and campus disciplinary committees are clearly not up to the task.

These young men are like the drunken student at a nearby college that I won't name, who barged into an elderly man's apartment thinking he was somewhere else and injured the man. They are privileged louts who think they can do anything. And they carry that attitude with them when they leave school. They are opportunists who will take advantage if they can. College-age women should know that those students are out there and that being drunk means you're vulnerable. And the rapists should be held accountable just like the above-mentioned student was.

As a lawyer, and mother of a college woman, I share the outrage of many that colleges have been so negligent in handling these serious crimes.  It's shocking that in 2014, it's the same old story - victims of rape are blamed and stigmatized.  It must stop.  I also must ask - who are these young men?  Why is this a common crime on every campus?  How were they raised, to think that they can rape a woman and not be subject to criminal penalties?

American jurisprudence, particularly in the area of rights, has long been an example for the world. That reputation evaporated over about the last decade. Now, like La Guardia, the US Supreme Court seems cramped, inhospitable and ill equipped to move the country forward. It is a narrow, ugly portal on a still vibrant, ambitious and generous nation. This is a loss whose effects are felt around the world.
Such matters should be dealt with by law enforcement agencies. I do not remember when universities were granted this role.

Derick, the overall point (although perhaps not made completely clear by this particular article) is that quite often universities will interfere in some way with legal due process. If an incident is reported to legal authorities, it becomes an official crime statistic that happened on their campus. There have been clear cut cases where sober victims were raped by someone they were not in any way involved with, and the universities were so powerful in a small town, that they even held sway over local law enforcement. They don't want parents of prospective students to know that x amount of sexual assaults occurred on campus - it's bad for business.

So as a graduate student in Public Health, physician and father of a college freshman daughter, I am appalled at the pass college student sexual predators are granted. True alcohol and " aggressive flirting " May blur the lines but No! means No! I tell my daughter to go to parties with friends she can trust and always have a designated sober friend present. Abstaining from binge drinking or recreational drug use is the best advice to follow but college students will need to experiment and as a last resort have pepper stay handy and use it where the boys will remember the experience the best and maybe understand No! In the future. As a concerned father who is not able to protect her daughter from all the predators in her life, asking college campus officials to do the right things and protect half the student body from traumatizing the other half is not unreasonable.
bearing false witness is a conundrum.

This is worth researching. In the event of a homicide, NYPD would step in immediately, so the only reason I can think of that NYPD would not have jurisdiction over a rape is because there is an agreement between the campus and the NPYD to leave those complaints to the administration. Columbia's security are probably not sworn peace officers, however, so this is all a strange arrangement that deserves to be investigated fully. There will be important facts that come out of that research.
It is a private institution. Even a state school can expel every student in a dorm room of the Resident Adviser or other admin smells cannabis - no special due process.

I don't think getting rid of co-ed housing would change anything, since as long as the school's co-ed men and women will be regularly getting together for social events.
That said, I strongly believe that separating men and women is not the answer. We need to be teaching everyone (men and women) that it is never okay to touch, let alone have sex with, someone without their consent. Separating them doesn't teach them how to behave around each other (as they inevitably will be), and it just continues the assumption that rapists are slaves to their libidos.
And when will these young people learn to live together in society, whilst respecting each other. Separating them is not a good solution to the problem.
I realize this is rank heresy, I suspect if campuses did away with co-ed housing instances of sexual abuse and harassment in our schools would drop dramatically.

Because they are kids and they don't know what else to do, especially since most are not raped by the stereotypical stranger in a dark alley.  The most vulnerable targets for campus sexual assaults are  known to be freshmen women in their first few months at college.  These are teenagers, often away from home for the first time.  They are targeted by predatory young men.  Ever hear the phrase "fresh meat"?  That is what it means on campuses nowadays.  College students who are raped will often turn first to a residential adviser or a staff person in residential/campus life.  They are often afraid to tell their parents what has happened, they blame themselves in part, and they often have no experience in dealing with police.  They aren't in their home communities.  They are traumatized and afraid.  I know what I will tell my daughter to do if this happens to her or a friend:  call the nearest rape crisis center and get a rape kit done by people who actually care about the victim.  University staff do care about victims, but they don't do rape kits.  And without evidence, the police and prosecutors won't do anything.

I am very very sympathetic with the victims and clearly things needs to change in how these crimes are dealt with on campus. I am not quite sure why the victims go the University rather than calling 911.
And why should being gay make a boy guilty?
@Sphinxfeather: concur, that "presumed innocent until proven guilty' is SO inconvenient.

If ever there was a need for a "consent education program", it is now.  The majority of young men are not rapists and do not engage in this type of violent sexual activity so the issue of rape is foreign to them.  This majority is, however, faced with the issue of "consent" and sexual assault.  They should be taught how to avoid situations in which there could be any doubt about consent, especially since the burden of determining it seems to be shifting to the male.

As the father of two sons, I want to remind everyone that boys have rights too. A girl cannot just point a finger at a boy and automatically ruin their education and life. The responsible media has to stop writing bias stories like this. Not every boy in college is guilty unless gay.

It is complicated.  I recall an assault by a man "friend" I'd know for years.  I was attracted to him, kissed him, but said no to sex.  When he assaulted me and I kept saying no, his attitude was that I wanted it.  I could have reported him, but didn't, could have fought more violently, but didn't why?  I liked him and didn't want to hurt his feelings.
Don't destroy the evidence! The cops have plenty of warehouse space where they can store your rape kit and forget about it.

As long as colleges and universities allow fraternities they are allowing and promoting rape culture.  Sorry but the facts bear out that the number of rapes in frats show them to be prime danger zones for women.  Of course the drinking frats are famous for is a contributing factor, as is the preponderance of youth with no sense of accountability.

Colleges and universities are much more involved in this issue than ever before. The issue is simply this: If it is a sexual assault, as in a crime, then is should go to the police and the prosecutors. The problem arises when the incident is not sexual assault, but the very complicated area of sex for young people first experiencing it. This problem is college and universities attempting to define and regulate those gray areas. There is simply no way for college administrators to become law enforcers in this complicated legal area.

Those who are victims of sexual assaults should go immediately to the police and press charges, and make sure that they do not destroy the evidence.

Well said. Upon reading, who doesn't cringe at the thought of such a kangaroo court? If such "courts" come from Title IX, whether the letter or its spirit, something definitely has to change. The notion that these "courts" have the color of federal law is repugnant.

On that last point, I do see what you're saying, but I don't completely agree.

Sexual assault is a useful term because people enact those behaviors without the other person's consent, which is in itself very bad and which if not harshly dealt with contributes to people (mostly men) thinking they have a right to other people's (mostly women's) bodies. There's a whole host of reasons why that's an incredibly damaging paradigm, not least of which that it perpetuates rape culture.

The E.U. doesn't have a leader, elected or otherwise.  Assuming that you were referring to Angela Merkel, she's the elected chancellor of Germany and has just about the same right to "scold" President Obama as he has to scold her.  In any case, if you were a world leader how would you feel about a putative ally who'd been spying on you?  As for Putin being her "best buddy," the fact remains that she's been going along with our President's economic sanctions even despite the fact that her country relies (far too heavily) on Russian petrol.  With friends like her...

Columbia and other universities actually do a great deal to try to address this issue. Not reported in this story is why the student didn't immediately call 911 and report this crime to the police. The NYPD would have been there in minutes, as they take sexual assault very seriously, and the victim would have been taken to nearby St. Luke's Hospital to be examined. She could have pressed criminal charges against the alleged assailant, and justice could have taken its course.

The fact that this incident was not reported for 8 months eliminated any possibility of having physical evidence of the attack, and put the university in an almost impossible position.
It was probably the worst experience of her life too. And if she was too drunk to give informed consent, she was raped.

How fortunate for any parent to have the time and the means to visit colleges with her child!  It's such an interesting time - when kids are on the cusp of adulthood.  Maybe that child is not yet mature enough to leave home? I couldn't decide whether the article was written as a joke, but then I couldn't see the humor in minimizing the experience and trivializing the children's involvement.

I apologize, that was poorly worded. I was just a bit worked up about your comment. I should not have said it was "terrible and uninformed" in a general sense (I strongly agree with the idea that we should all be improving ourselves by studying - I go to Columbia, myself, and most of the time will choose to study instead of going out) but as a response to this issue I find it to be very problematic to tell women that they should just "stay home and study." Why should this be advice to women only? By making this statement you're asserting that it's the woman's fault for being assaulted by choosing to go out and socialize with their peers rather than always remaining at home, working and studying alone. That's absurd.

Yes, we should all stay home and study as much as possible; it will make us successful and keep us safe. But telling women they should just "stay home and study" actively prohibits them from feeling as if they have a right to enter into social spaces and from feeling that they will be protected if they experience sexual assault while socializing, whether sober or intoxicated. By saying such a thing you perpetuate the idea that it's a woman's fault if she is assaulted.

Oh come on! The only trend Mr. Bruni notes that is worth worrying about is the economic stagnation of the middle class and poor. And the reason that is happening is because of our hideously unfair tax system, which lets hedge fund managers pay a lower tax rate than janitors; an antipathy to public spending that allows our schools to crumble and turn violent while our banks have banner years; and a health care system which costs twice as much as anyone else's, with worse results. Once the deeply frightened, totally irresponsible, and deeply weird people now dominating the Republican party have aged out, presumably we can get back to being a civic-minded, fair, and optimistic country.

The other trends he seems to be worried about - America "walking small;" China having a bigger total economy (NOT a bigger per-capita economy, by a long shot, though you would never know that by reading Bruni); "reduced" international expectations - are just the made-up worried of overgrown boys, deeply insecure and needing to puff out their chests. If America becomes less expansionist and interventionist internationally, the entire rest of the world will breathe a sigh of relief. That is good news, not bad!
